gauzy: A gauzy object looks like it is made of a thin, transparent fabric.
A "gauzy" thing looks like a piece of thin, translucent fabric.
meshed: A meshed thing looks like it is made of a net or netting.
A meshed surface is a smooth surface with a network of small holes or pores.
cracked: A cracked thing looks like it is broken into two or more pieces.
A cracked texture generally looks like a series of small cracks in the surface of an object.
stratified: A stratified pattern has a layering effect, with different elements placed at different levels.
A stratified thing is usually layered, with each layer having a different composition.
scaly: A scaly object has a lot of small, thin scales on its surface.
A scaly surface is a surface that is covered in small, thin scales.
swirly: A "swirly" surface usually looks like a spiral or a series of loops.
Swirly material is material with a lot of small, intricate patterns.
perforated: When something is perforated, it has small holes all over it.
Perforated material is a material that has been punctured with small holes.
pleated: Pleated fabric is fabric that has been folded or gathered into pleats.
Pleated textures are commonly seen in clothing, such as skirts or pants.
flecked: A "flecked" texture is a small speckled or mottled pattern on a larger surface.
A "flecked" pattern is one that is dotted or spotted with a different color or material.
fibrous: A fibrous material looks like a bunch of fibers woven together.
fibrous objects are usually dull in color and have a rough texture.
polka-dotted: A polka-dotted texture looks like a texture with small, round bumps.
A polka-dotted surface is covered in small, round spots.
chequered: A chequered surface consists of a series of small, regularly-spaced raised squares.
A chequered texture has a regular pattern of light and dark squares.
blotchy: A blotchy surface can refer to a number of different things, but generally it is an uneven surface with patches of discoloration.
A blotchy thing is a thing that has blotches on it.
stained: A "stained" thing is covered in a substance that is not supposed to be there.
A "stained" texture usually looks like a fabric that has had something spilled on it and has a dark discoloration.
crystalline: The term "crystalline" refers to the orderly arrangement of atoms in a material.
A "crystalline" pattern looks like a clear, geometric pattern.
porous: A "porous" thing is something that has small holes in it.
A porous thing can have small holes or be permeable to fluids and gases.
banded: A banded thing is usually a long, thin strip of material, such as cloth or paper, that is wrapped around something else.
A "banded" thing has stripes or markings that go around it.
lacelike: Lace is a delicate fabric made of intertwining threads.
A lacelike surface has a delicate, intricate, and open structure.
sprinkled: A "sprinkled" texture looks like a piece of paper that has been sprinkled with glitter.
A sprinkled thing is covered in small pieces or dots.
bubbly: A bubbly object can have a lot of small bubbles or a few large bubbles.
A "bubbly" texture looks like it has tiny bubbles in it, like soda or champagne.
lined: A lined material is a type of fabric that has a second layer of fabric underneath the outer layer.
A lined surface has straight lines running across it.
veined: A veined pattern typically features darker lines or streaks against a lighter background.
Veined materials have lines or streaks running through them.
bumpy: A "bumpy" surface has protrusions or indentations that make it uneven.
A "bumpy" object can have many different shapes, but is generally characterized by having a lot of small bumps on its surface.
paisley: A paisley object is typically ornate and colorful, with a distinctively recurring motif of a teardrop-shaped vegetable.
Paisley is a design that is made up of curved shapes that resemble teardrops or comma shapes.
potholed: Potholed material is typically cracked and full of holes.
A potholed texture looks like a bunch of small holes in the surface.
waffled: A waffled pattern looks like a waffle.
"Waffled" material is material that is made up of a series of small, raised ridges.
pitted: A pitted surface is one that has small craters or indentations.
A pitted pattern has resemble small depressions or holes in the surface.
frilly: The best way to describe frilly fabric is to say that it is fabric with a lot of ruffles.
A frilly pattern looks like a pattern with a lot of small details.
spiralled: A "spiralled" texture looks like a spiral or a coil.
A spiralled pattern can look like a spiral staircase or a coil.
knitted: Knitted objects are typically composed of straight, parallel lines of stitches that are interlocked together in a certain pattern.
Knitted objects are typically composed of straight, parallel lines of stitches that are interlocked together in a certain pattern.
grooved: A grooved surface usually has parallel lines cut into it.
"Grooved" can mean different things depending on the context, but typically a grooved texture is one that has parallel lines running across it.
dotted: A dotted texture means that there are small raised dots on the surface of the fabric.
A dotted thing has a series of small dots in a line or pattern.
interlaced: An interlaced texture is a texture that has been created by combining two or more separate images into a single image.
Interlaced materials have a visible striped pattern.
crosshatched: The lines on a crosshatched object are drawn in opposite directions, usually at a 45 degree angle.
A crosshatched pattern is a series of crossed lines that form a grid.
wrinkled: Wrinkled material looks like it has wrinkles.
A wrinkled surface looks like a surface that has been folded or creased.
smeared: A smeared material would have a streaky or blurry appearance.
A smeared object may appear to have a blurry or fuzzy edge.
striped: A striped surface looks like a surface that has been divided into a series of vertical stripes.
A striped thing has lines or bands going across it.
braided: A braided object has two or more strands that are woven together in a pattern.
A braided surface can look like a series of interlocking loops, or it can look like a series of intersecting lines.
freckled: Materials that are freckled usually have small spots of color on them.
A freckled thing has small, brown spots on its skin.
cobwebbed: Cobwebbed material is covered with a thin layer of dust or debris.
The texture of a cobweb is usually thin, delicate, and lacy.
honeycombed: Honeycombed material looks like a series of hexagonal cells that are all interconnected.
A honeycombed object has a series of hexagonal or round cavities.
woven: A woven object looks like a fabric that has been created by interlacing two sets of threads at right angles to each other.
A woven pattern looks like a fabric that has been woven together.
matted: Matted material is material that is tangled and stuck together.
The term "matted" typically refers to a material that is tangled, knotted, or otherwise stuck together in a clump.
zigzagged: A zigzag texture looks like a series of diagonal lines.
A "zigzagged" object has a series of sharp angles, like the letter "Z".
marbled: A marbled surface is a surface with a pattern that looks like it was made by swirling different colors of paint or ink together.
A marbled object is one that has a streaked or swirled pattern, like that of marble.
studded: Studded material is typically a leather or fabric material that has metal studs affixed to it in a decorative manner.
A studded thing has small metal ornaments sticking out of it.
grid: Grid material looks like a network of squares.
A grid pattern is a repeating, evenly spaced set of lines that intersect each other to form a series of squares or rectangles.
